answer_html: It is easy to see that 1,2,4,7 are not in \(T\).
answer_latex:
It is easy
to see that 1,2,4,7 are not in $T$.
hints_html: Show that you can get every positive integer except 1, 2, 4 and 7.
hints_latex: Show that you can get every positive integer except 1, 2, 4 and 7.
hints_raw: Show that you can get every positive integer except 1, 2, 4 and 7.
sols_html:
Let \(x\in \mathbb{N}\).

Case 1

\[\begin{aligned} x=3k\end{aligned}\]

for some \(k\in \mathbb{N}\).

In this case we write \(x\) as a sum of \(k\) 3’s.

Case 2

\[\begin{aligned} x=3k+2\end{aligned}\]

for some \(k\in \mathbb{N}\) with \(k\geq 1\).

In this case we write \(x = 3k+2 = 3(k-1)+5\) as the sum of \(k-1\) 3’s and one 5.

Case 3

\[\begin{aligned} x=3k+1\end{aligned}\]

for some \(k\in \mathbb{N}\) with \(k\geq 3\).

In this case we write \(x = 3(k-3)+10\) as the sum of \(k-3\) 3’s and two 5’s.

This shows that all numbers other than 1,2,4,7 belong to \(T\). It is easy to see that 1,2,4,7 are not in \(T\).
sols_latex:
Let $x\in \mathbb{N}$.

Case 1\begin{align*}
x=3k
\end{align*} for some $k\in \mathbb{N}$.

In this case we write $x$ as a sum of $k$ 3's.

Case 2\begin{align*}
x=3k+2
\end{align*} for some $k\in \mathbb{N}$ with $k\geq 1$.

In this case we write $x = 3k+2 = 3(k-1)+5$ as the sum of $k-1$ 3's and
one 5.

Case 3\begin{align*}
x=3k+1
\end{align*} for some $k\in \mathbb{N}$ with $k\geq 3$.

In this case we write $x = 3(k-3)+10$ as the sum of $k-3$ 3's and two
5's.

This shows that all numbers other than 1,2,4,7 belong to $T$. It is easy
to see that 1,2,4,7 are not in $T$.
sols_raw:
Let <math> x\in \mathbb{N} </math>. 

Case 1: <math> x=3k</math> for some <math> k\in \mathbb{N}</math>. 

In this case we write <math> x </math> as a sum of <math> k </math> 3's.

Case 2: <math> x=3k+2</math> for some <math> k\in \mathbb{N}</math> with <math> k\geq 1</math>.

In this case we write <math> x = 3k+2 = 3(k-1)+5 </math> as the sum of <math> k-1 </math> 3's and one 5.

Case 3: <math> x=3k+1</math> for some <math> k\in \mathbb{N}</math> with <math> k\geq 3</math>.

In this case we write <math> x = 3(k-3)+10 </math> as the sum of <math> k-3 </math> 3's and two 5's.

This shows that all numbers other than 1,2,4,7 belong to <math> T </math>. It is easy to see that 1,2,4,7 are not in <math> T </math>.
statement_html: Let T be the set of all natural numbers that can be written as some nonnegative number of 3\(^{\prime}\)s plus some nonnegative number of 5\(^{\prime}\)s. For example, 9 = 3 + 3 + 3 and 10 = 5+5 and 17 = 3+3+3+3+5 are all in T, but 4 is not. Determine T (with justification).
statement_latex:
Let \emph{T} be the set of all natural numbers that can be written as
some nonnegative number of 3$^{\prime}$s plus some nonnegative number of
5$^{\prime}$s. For example, 9 = 3 + 3 + 3 and 10 = 5+5 and 17 =
3+3+3+3+5 are all in \emph{T}, but 4 is not. Determine \emph{T} (with
justification).
statement_raw: Let ''T'' be the set of all natural numbers that can be written as some nonnegative number of 3’s plus some nonnegative number of 5’s. For example, 9 = 3 + 3 + 3 and 10 = 5+5 and 17 = 3+3+3+3+5 are all in ''T'', but 4 is not. Determine ''T'' (with justification).
